thought.author: Martin Fowler
description: In a professional environment, the ratio of time spent reading versus writing code is about 10 to 1. Producing clean, comprehensive and maintainable code is of utmost importance and leads to increased team effectiveness. Here's nice quote from Thought Works Martin Fowler which sums it up quite nicely.
thought.quote: Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.

thought.author: Harold Abelson
description: Following up on yesterday's issue of #ThoughtsOfProgramming and the idea of producing clean, comprehensive and maintainable code to increase team effectiveness, here's another very valid point by Harold Abelson.
thought.quote: Programs must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute.

thought.author: Douglas Crockford
description: Any run-of-the-mill idiot can produce code that a machine can execute, but good programmers write code that mortals can actually comprehend and reason about. Today's #ThoughtsOnProgramming features Douglas Crockford, inventor of the JSON format with a reminder on why style matters.
thought.quote: It turns out that style matters in programming for the same reason that it matters in writing. It makes for better reading.
